Well, the Good, the Bad and Ugly.Â  I had a 6x6 Bigfoot, complete with windshield, wipers, canvas top, outboard bracket and tracks and winch.Â  The Ugly, Got it second hand with low hours and it needed a bit of TLC, mostly wiping out the inside from having been put away wet, the carb needed a rebuild, dirty gas and gum.Â  Briggs & Stratton engine was a bit of a birch at times,Â  the throttle mechanism didn't have an accelerator pump so you couldn't give it full gas and go, it would stutter a bit and then go.Â  Once I figured that out, it was ok.Â  It also needed 3 new axle bearings,Â  easy enough to remove and replace,Â  they are a common size.Â  The Bad, well they can be a bit of a rough ride, you have to learn not to go over the rough ground at warp speed.Â  Add a gel cushion and it's remarkably better.Â  On flat ground they are fine.Â  The Good,Â  darn things near unstoppable unless you really want to bury it somewhere with a dead body in it, lol.Â  With the standard width track I never got stuck either, it would pretty well float on the snow.Â  For glare ice, there is a cleat kit for the tracks, gives more steering response.Â Â  The newer ones have a lot of upgrades in steering, brakes, alternator output, etc.Â  Why did I get rid of mine?Â  They are not allowed on club ATV trails, they don't fall under the 4/6 wheel ATV bracket that the clubs pay landowner insurance for.Â  Mine was plated/insured, etc and never had a problem driving down the side of the road to get onto Simcoe, local PD guys looked smiled and said carry on.Â Â  If you go with tracks, remember it will effect trailer width,Â  if you have an enclosed trailer,Â  figure out how you're going to get out unless you want to climb over stuff.

Fisherman sent me an e-mail asking, somewhat incredulously, if I bought another Argo.Â  Guilty as charged.Â  Then I went looking for this thread.Â  (You could have sent me a link, buddy............) I did own one many moons ago, an 8 wheeler with the so-called Super Tracks (extra wide).Â  It cost me several hundred dollars for every kilometer I ever drove it.Â  But I am not in any way mechanically inclined so could not do any of the work it needed. I did fish out of it a number of times.Â  It is very bow-heavy and if you have two men in the front seat you don't have much freeboard.Â  Unless you put a kicker motor on it, your propulsion is just the tires, so excruciatingly slow.Â  I did have a motor bracket, AND a bilge pump! With the tracks yes you can go just about anywhere, but once you are stuck, you are well and truly bogged.Â  I got bogged in slush about half-way up the hull one time, and that was a very exciting adventure indeed.Â  The young lad (Drew) that runs a tackle shop in Owen Sound still has nightmares about it...ğŸ˜‰ There is no suspension, just the tires, so it is not a smooth ride over bumps and obstacles.Â  This is the case both with and without the tracks mounted. BUT!!!!!Â  they FLOAT, so if a person is ice fishing and goes through the ice, you are not going to drown.Â  You may die of hypothermia, but the bodies will be easy to find. The new models are a huge improvement over the old ones, much less inclined to break down.Â  You can mount a winch both on the front and on the back for gnarly spots, but of course there has to be something solid to hook up the winch cable. I decided to buy this new one because of the safety factor for ice fishing, and because it is VERY handy around my hunting property.Â  I can generally drive right up to a dead deer and just lift it into the back end. Cliff, I don't really believe this is the rig for you, but by all means if you want to drive one, come on down to Kingston and be my guest. Doug
